keyTakeAways: A fire broke out at Hungary’s Danube Refinery in Százhalombatta, a key oil-processing facility, on Monday night, with no injuries reported.
The fire occurred in a processing unit, and the cause is under investigation; emergency protocols were followed.
Hungary’s only major crude-processing facility relies heavily on Russian oil, despite the EU-wide push to reduce Russian energy imports.
Hungary has maintained and even increased its Russian oil imports since 2022, asserting there is no viable alternative.
The EU has implemented an embargo on Russian oil and plans to cease all Russian oil and gas imports by 2027.
MOL, Hungary’s state-owned energy company, confirmed the incident and emphasized maintaining domestic fuel supplies, potentially using strategic reserves.
Prime Minister Viktor Orbán confirmed that Hungary’s fuel supply is secure and stated the incident is being investigated thoroughly.
Air quality around the refinery was monitored and no health-limit breaches were detected.
Eyewitnesses reported visible flames and smoke from several kilometers away, indicating the scale and visibility of the incident.
The facility’s own fire brigade responded first, with support from professional firefighters from nearby cities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fire broke out overnight at Hungary’s Danube Refinery in Százhalombatta, the country’s sole major crude-processing facility, with no injuries reported. The incident occurred during a period of increased EU-wide efforts to phase out Russian energy imports, making Hungary’s continued reliance on Russian oil a notable policy anomaly. MOL, Hungary’s state-owned energy company, confirmed the fire, stated that emergency protocols were followed, and emphasized that domestic fuel supplies remain secure, potentially using strategic reserves. Prime Minister Viktor Orbán affirmed fuel security and declared the investigation into the blaze ongoing. Air quality monitoring found no health risks, and eyewitnesses reported visible flames and smoke over several kilometers. The fire underscores Hungary’s unique energy strategy in contrast to the rest of Europe, and highlights the risks associated with dependence on foreign energy sources amid geopolitical shifts.
title: Fire at Hungary’s Main Oil Refinery Sparks Investigation Amid EU Energy Shift
